title: Book project: The Machinery of Manipulation
text:
Ruling parties in authoritarian regimes have a broad range of tools with which to influence election outcomes, including ballot-stuffing, falsification, voter-pressure, vote-buying, and more. What limits authoritarian incumbents‚Äô ability to manipulate elections in their favor using these tools? What enables such manipulation?
These questions get to the heart of contemporary non-democratic government. The average authoritarian regime today relies on regular, multiparty elections to perpetuate itself in office.

title: Cole J. Harvey, PhD
text:
Assistant Professor of Political Science
Oklahoma State University


 ORCID
 Google Scholar
 BlueSky
 Email






Hello and welcome! ¬†I am a political scientist who studies non-democratic politics, with a particular focus on electoral manipulation in authoritarian and hybrid regimes. My geographic area of expertise is Russia and the post-communist world. I received my PhD from the University of North Carolina ‚Äì Chapel Hill in May 2019; I held a post-doctoral fellowship at the Center for Russia, East Europe, and Central Asia at the University of Wisconsin ‚Äì Madison, and am currently an assistant professor at Oklahoma State University.

üìÑ Curriculum Vitae
üìò Book project: The Machinery of Manipulation

I use multiple tools in my research, including statistical analysis, methods for causal inference (such as regression-discontinuity designs and pre-processing techniques), field interviews, archival study, and survey-experimental research. My work has been published in the American Political Science Review, Electoral Studies, Democratization, and Government and Opposition,¬†Europe-Asia Studies, and Russian Politics.
